speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: SCENE III. OLIVIA'S house.

speaker: VIOLA
text_entry: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o'

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: nights: your cousin, my lady, takes great

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: exceptions to your ill hours.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Why, let her except, before excepted.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: limits of order.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Confine! I'll confine myself no finer than I am:

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: these clothes are good enough to drink in; and so be

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: these boots too: an they be not, let them hang

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: themselves in their own straps.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, he.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: What's that to the purpose?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats:

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he's a very fool and a prodigal.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o' the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: word for word without book, and hath all the good

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: gifts of nature.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: He hath indeed, almost natural: for besides that

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he's a fool, he's a great quarreller: and but that

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought among the prudent

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: By this hand, they are scoundrels and subtractors

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: that say so of him. Who are they?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: With drinking healths to my niece: I'll drink to

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her as long as there is a passage in my throat and

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: drink in Illyria: he's a coward and a coystrill

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: o' the toe like a parish-top. What, wench!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Castiliano vulgo! for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Enter SIR ANDREW

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir Toby Belch!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Sweet Sir Andrew!

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Bless you, fair shrew.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: And you too, sir.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: What's that?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: My niece's chambermaid.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: My name is Mary, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Good Mistress Mary Accost,--

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: You mistake, knight; 'accost' is front her, board

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her, woo her, assail her.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: company. Is that the meaning of 'accost'?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Fare you well, gentlemen.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: never draw sword again.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: fools in hand?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Marry, but you shall have; and here's my hand.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Now, sir, 'thought is free:' I pray you, bring

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Wherefore, sweet-heart? what's your metaphor?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: It's dry, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Why, I think so: I am not such an ass but I can

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: A dry jest, sir.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Are you full of them?

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry,

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: now I let go your hand, I am barren.

speaker: MARIA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: O knight thou lackest a cup of canary: when did I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: see thee so put down?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Never in your life, I think; unless you see canary

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: than a Christian or an ordinary man has: but I am a

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: great eater of beef and I believe that does harm to my wit.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: No question.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: An I thought that, I'ld forswear it. I'll ride home

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: to-morrow, Sir Toby.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: What is 'Pourquoi'? do or not do? I would I had

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: fencing, dancing and bear-baiting: O, had I but

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: followed the arts!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Why, would that have mended my hair?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Past question; for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: But it becomes me well enough, does't not?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Excellent; it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: hope to see a housewife take thee between her legs

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: and spin it off.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir Toby: your niece

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: will not be seen; or if she be, it's four to one

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: she'll none of me: the count himself here hard by woos her.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: She'll none o' the count: she'll not match above

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: have heard her swear't. Tut, there's life in't,

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: man.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: strangest mind i' the world; I delight in masques

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: and revels sometimes altogether.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: degree of my betters; and yet I will not compare

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: with an old man.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Faith, I can cut a caper.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: And I can cut the mutton to't.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: as any man in Illyria.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Wherefore are these things hid? wherefore have

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: these gifts a curtain before 'em? are they like to

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? why dost

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: a coranto? My very walk should be a jig; I would not

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: flame-coloured stock. Shall we set about some revels?

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: What shall we do else? were we not born under Taurus?

speaker: SIR ANDREW
text_entry: Taurus! That's sides and heart.

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: No, sir; it is legs and thighs. Let me see the

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: caper; ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent!

speaker: SIR TOBY BELCH
text_entry: Exeunt
